title: 109_s3514
content: The Act may be cited as the "Social Security Number Online Protection Act of 2006". The inappropriate display of social security account numbers has led to various illegal activities, including fraud and identity theft, affecting interstate commerce and public safety. Social security numbers are required for tax purposes, benefits under the Social Security Act, and employment, but their misuse can facilitate crime and invasion of privacy. The misuse of social security account numbers has led to crime, fraud, and privacy invasions. The Federal Government should take steps to prevent abuse of these numbers. In many jurisdictions, public documents like business filings and birth certificates are accessible to the general public. The increasing online availability of public records, including business filings and birth certificates, poses a risk of social security account numbers being widely displayed and misused. The new chapter prohibits state and local governments from displaying the last 4 digits of social security account numbers on the internet. The new chapter prohibits state and local governments from displaying the last 4 digits of social security account numbers on the internet. This includes any officer, employee, or contractor of a State or political subdivision. It does not override stricter restrictions in Federal or State laws. Penalties are outlined for non-compliance. Sec. 2732 prohibits the display of social security account numbers on the internet, with penalties of up to $5,000 a day for noncompliance. The Attorney General can enforce this against states, political subdivisions, or individuals. Sec. 2733 allows the Attorney General to take legal action against states, political subdivisions, or individuals for displaying the last 4 digits of a social security account number on the internet in violation of section 2731. Sec. 2734 defines "display to the general public on the internet" as placing any part of a social security account number in a viewable manner on a publicly accessible internet site. "Displaying social security numbers online to the public is prohibited, including the last 4 digits, with legal action possible against violators." The prohibition against displaying social security numbers online extends to any state entity or individual requiring transmission of such numbers without proper encryption. The term "person" excludes states and their agencies. The term 'person' excludes states and their agencies, and a social security account number is defined as the number assigned by the Commissioner of Social Security. The amendment prohibits state and local governments from displaying social security account numbers on the internet. Grants are provided to help them comply with the prohibition on displaying the last 4 digits of social security account numbers. Effective date applies to violations occurring after the enactment of the Act. The Attorney General awards grants to States and political subdivisions to remove or redact the last 4 digits of social security numbers from public records displayed online. States must apply for grants following guidelines set by the Attorney General. Authorization of appropriations is provided for this purpose. The Attorney General awards grants to States and political subdivisions to redact social security numbers from online public records. States must apply for grants as per guidelines. $10,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2007 and 2008. Definition of "State" includes 50 States, DC, Puerto Rico, US Virgin Islands, Guam, and Northern Marianas.
